events.name: Blind Tennis Hackathon -- Building a Better Ball
events.about:
Blind Tennis Hackathon -- Building a Better Ball

This workshop is ideal for anyone interested in hacking tennis balls, sensors, or blind tennis. Blind tennis is much like sighted tennis except that the ball makes noise so that a blind or partially sighted player can track and return it. The ball that players currently use contains a rattle, so the sound it makes is intermittent. In addition, the movement of the rattle can affect the trajectory of the ball in unexpected ways. The aim of our workshop is to change that. Well investigate hacks along several tracks. First, mechanical hacks such as whistles or more balanced rattles. Second, electronic hacks ranging from a constant tone emitter to more complex solution involving sensors like accelerometers or gyroscopes. And third, methods of mounting our apparatus into balls.

Lunch will be provided. Those interested in sensors should bring their own laptops. Registration is $20 to cover materials and food.

events.name: AngelHack Fall 2012 Toronto: Michigan Hackers Edition
events.about:
15/11 UPDATE: Good news everyone! Ticket sales reopened. With the help of the fantastic folks at the Burroughes, we now have access to the 6th floor!
- Shaharris 

********
13/11 UPDATE: Maxxed out! Please sign up for our waitlist while we wrangle more space. Well notify you when more tickets are available. Thanks for your patience! - Shaharris 
 
********

Need a team? Come out to the next Hackernest Tech Social on Monday, November 26th.

Participant demographics (as of Nov 9): 
- expectations blown; over 250 registrations and climbing (its going to be cramped, elbow-to-elbow, and glorious... prep yourself)
- event volunteers: 4 (probably need 6-7 more <3)

- 75% dev, 13% ux/design, 12% biz/mktg 
- average age: ~24 years 
- 7:1 male-to-female ratio (whoa)
- 99% of respondents requested high fives 
- most common dude name: Jason 
- most common dudette name: Sarah

********

Ready to take your big idea to the next level? Then join us for Torontos first AngelHack! Winning teams receive 6-8 weeks of expert mentorship and are flown to Silicon Valley to showcase their projects to high-profile tech investors and media. The event-filled weekend also includes site visits to top tech startups and VCs, VIP dinners, and ridiculously fun parties.

This is not your typical hackathon; this is the big leagues.
 
AngelHack Fall 2012 Fast Facts
  • 2500 amazing developers & designers in 11 cities worldwide for you to work with
  • Great food, swag, nerf guns, helicopters, and awesomness all around
  • Over $650,000 in prizes, including trips to Silicon Valley for the top 25 teams
  • Media coverage and all-star investor judges to help validate those whacky hack ideas of yours

Wanna score a free ticket to AngelHack Toronto? BizSpark has 50 free tickets to give away to members ofMicrosoft BizSpark. Contact bizsparkca@microsoft.com to see how you can get one.


What should I build?
Create a prototype (hack) of something that you believe solves a big problem. You dont need a business plan or anything silly like that, but you should be able to show the big idea potential of your hack. AngelHack is a launchpad for you to flush out and validate projects youve always wanted to build. Previous winners include: Appetas, GiveGo, TapFame, SnapStore, ShareBrowse, Kloutron, & Blue Dragon Security.


What are the rules?
All code must be FRESH. Prior to the hackathon you can create your design, wireframes, logo, and user flows. You can even build hardware. But to make things completely fair, you cannot write any code whatsoever until the hackathon starts. All code must be put together at AngelHack. Youre on your honour.

 

Slideshow how itll magically work presentations = autofail. Demos actually have to be demos.

For more info visit our Rules and FAQ pages.


Good luck,
Gregory Gopman
AngelHack Founder / CEO

As seen in


*tickets are non-refundable

events.name: Hacking Health Follow Up
events.about:
To keep the momentum of Hacking Health @ MaRS going, we are inviting participants of Hacking Health and our network of mentors and experts to an evening of networking and discussion on Health Tech: 

Learn about how teams have progressed on from the hackathon and join a discussion on the challenges and opportunities for health tech startups in Toronto and Canada. We are in the process of finalizing the program but if you have any suggestions on what youd like to hear, please let us know. 

Were hosting our follow up event, the night before Angel Hack which is an excellent opportunity for teams to continue the momentum on their projects from Hacking Health @ MaRS and be connected to a wide range of resources. 

If youd like to make a presentation on your Hacking Health project, email us at contact@hackinghealth.ca
events.address: MaRS Center, Heritage Building, 2nd Floor 101 College Street

events.name: Hackernest Toronto Tech Social Special Edition: AngelHack Team Matching
events.about:
Need an AngelHack team?

Find your partners in crime here.

Youve 60 seconds to pitch your idea. PROTIP: Be memorable.

Last chance to form teams before the hackathon on December 1st & 2nd. We suggest you do this now, because things will get pretty hectic at the event. Use comments below to post what youre looking for.

********

This month, the generous folks over at Achievers (ex-I Love Rewards) are opening up their office to us. Theyve a fantastic story to tell and if youre lucky, they might just do so.

Awesome gold sponsor:

The fantastic team at Grossman Dorland Recruiting -
exceptionally talented at finding exceptionally talented people

 

Gracious space sponsor:

Achievers (once upon a time, I Love Rewards) - employee rewards and recognition done right - with $38.1 million dollars in funding... ZOMG

events.name: WOWZAPP 2012: Worldwide Hackathon for Windows -- Toronto, Canada
events.about:
Be part of the app revolution!

By registering, you’ll be joining thousands of developers worldwide as we build apps for the next generation of Windows.

Expert Help, Free Resources

Microsoft app experts, developers and trainers will be available on-site to assist your learning and coding. Learn about building Windows Store apps today – download the info, tools and resources you need now. 

Windows Azure Mobile Services

Does your Store app idea include cloud services or storage? Check out Get started withMobile Services –registered student WOWZAPP 2012 participants are eligible for a FREE temporary student Windows Azure subscription!– supplies are limited so be sure to register now!

events.name: Ladies Learning Code Hack Day
events.about:
Hey you! Have you joined the Ladies Learning Code email list? If not, click here.

What is Ladies Learning Code?

Were a not-for-profit startup in Toronto who provide women (and men*) the opportunity to learn beginner-friendly computer programming and other technical skills in a social and collaborative way. Were all about showing people that learning to hack can be fun!

*Men are welcome to attend workshops (and they do!), but we request that you bring with you an additional female learner where possible.

Why a Hack Day?

Sometimes, you want a structured learning experience, like a Ladies Learning Code workshop. But sometimes, you just want to work on a project! Whether you want to take something you learned at a Ladies Learning Code workshop to the next level, need help installing a Wordpress theme, or want to add some JavaScript to your personal website, the Ladies Learning Code Hack Day is for you!

Essentially, Ladies Learning Code Hack Day is a day dedicated to taking your web skills to the next level – no matter what stage you’re at. Beginners are welcome, but even our more experienced community members will find value in the day. There’s no specific content and we can’t tell you what you’ll learn in advance – because it depends on the personal project you bring along with you. As usual, this event will be supported by some of Toronto’s most talented developers – we call them “Mentors” – who will be there to help you throughout the day! Were aiming for a 4:1 ratio or better of participants to Mentors, so if youd like to help out as a technical volunteer, please join our tech help mailing list here.

Note that this Hack Day is dedicated to website projects – anything related to creating websites is fair game! That includes HTML & CSS, Wordpress, JavaScript, jQuery, web design, and more!

Here are some examples of projects you could work on at the Ladies Learning Code Hack Day:

  • Get help purchasing a domain name and hosting – or finally make use of a domain name you purchased ages ago!
  • Learn to build a simple webpage using  HTML & CSS
  • Learn to install and tweak a Wordpress theme (such as one from Themify.me!)
  • Add some JavaScript to a website you’ve created on your own
  • Install a widget, tweak some code on your website, add a contact form – feel free to get creative!
 

Is this workshop for you?

This workshop has been designed for beginners who have never been exposed to JavaScript before, but already have basic knowledge of HTML and CSS. Not sure if you have the basic HTML and CSS youll need to get the most out of this workshop? If youve been to either of our Intro to HTML & CSS workshops (and paid attention), you should be good to go! Missed those workshops? See this quiz. If you can answer the 3 questions, you are probably a good fit for the October 13th workshop!

Requirements:

  1. No experience necessary, but it may help to have a project in mind when you arrive. Email us at info [at] ladieslearningcode.com if you have any questions or need ideas! Remember, beginners are welcome!
  2. You must own or have access to a laptop with wi-fi for which you have administrative permissions. Please be sure to bring your powercord.

Also, if you can bring a travel mug to the workshop, that would be great! Were trying to make our workshops more eco-friendly.

*Are you quaified to help out this workshop? Great - our workshops absolutely wouldnt be possible without the incredible developers who help us out! Please join our tech help email list here.

Whats Included?

  • A small ratio (usually 4:1!) of participants to instructors - get the help you need!
  • A fun and inclusive learning envionment
  • A great venue (The Ladies Learning Code space at The Centre for Social Innovation)
  • Delicious snacks
  • A free Wordpress theme from Themify.me (Thanks, @Themify!)

Questions?

Email us at info [at] ladieslearningcode.com. You can also find us here:

Twitter: @llcodedotcom (dont forget to use the hashtag: #ladieslearningcode)
Facebook: facebook.com/ladieslearningcode
Mailing List & Developer/Designer Mailing List: http://ladieslearningcode.com

What participants say about our workshops:

Honestly, the set up of one instructor - four students is brilliant.

Im super impressed with the organizers and participants, and I think its a really valuable initiative.

[The best part of the workshop was] the positivity, helpfulness and eagerness to learn/teach of every person in the room.

After years of teaching myself how to code, I wasnt sure how Id find the collaborative experience of an LLC workshop - but it completely exceeded my expectations. The lead instructor was clear and thorough, and the volunteer instructors were always ready to throw new challenges at us the moment they saw wed completed the current task. Solving a coding problem has always been exciting for me, but having a group of people equally excited about it was amazing!

[My favourite part was] the casual nature of things, and the fact that all the instructors walked around and helped out learners everywhere around the room - so I got to meet and talk to a bunch of people who were experienced and gain some perspectives. The food was great too. ;)

events.name: Hacking Health Toronto
events.about:
Hacking Health is a weekend long hackathon where clinicians pitch projects to technological innovators. Health professionals, developers and designers combine forces to build realistic, human-centric solutions to front- line healthcare problems.

Our unique hackathon brings together clinical experts and health though leaders, passionate technial talent, and health IT leadership from both the private and public sector. 

For more information, visit our website at www.hackinghealth.ca

events.name: Palm Mobile Development - Hackathon
events.about:
Open webOS Hackathon With Roy Sutton, Engineer at Palm 

Open webOS is the first open-source version of webOS released on September 28, 2012 from Palm. In the two days that Open webOS has been released, it’s already been ported to an HP TouchSmart all in one PC, a Galaxy Nexus, an Asus Transformer Prime and a Raspberry Pi computer. We will try to make history at Semaphore Lab by inviting the Toronto hacking community to hack Open webOS on an Android device to be determined!

events.name: Uken Games Hackathon - You're Next Career Network
events.about:
Hackathon Logistics

What: Uken Games challenges you to build a game
Where:  ECF lab 
When: Friday,  October 12th @ 6pm  - Saturday, October 13th @ 6pm
Who: All undergrads interested in coding (Registration Required)    

Why: Immerse yourself in the startup environment and take on the challenge of building a mobile game in 24 hours! Come out and enjoy the night with other like-minded coders. Food and other refreshments will be provided throughout the competition.

Prizes: Winners will receive an internship interview with Uken Games - a mobile game development startup based in Toronto.

Teams: Up to 4 people/team

Languages: Any language of your choice (just remember to be cognisant of time!)

Platform: Any Mobile or Web Apps

Schedule:

Friday Oct. 12, 2012
6 pm - 6:15 pm: Registration
6:15 pm - 6:30 pm: Introduction from Uken Games and the Challenge
6:30 pm: Competition starts

Saturday Oct. 13, 2012
6:00 pm: Competition finishes
6:00 pm - 7:00 pm: Presentation and Judging

events.name: Hacking Health Toronto Meet Up
events.about:
When
6pm-8pm, September 26th 2012

Where
Centre for Global eHealth Innovation
190 Elizabeth Street, R. Fraser Elliott Building, 4th Floor (enter from Elizabeth Street and take the South elevators up across from Tim Hortons), Toronto General Hospital
Tel: 416.340.5514

Join us at the Centre for Global eHealth Innovation for a casual meet up (with free pizza!) to launch Hacking Health Toronto! Learn more about the Hacking Health weekend and preview some of the project proposals.

The brief program includes:

  • Presentation on the Hacking Health weekend   
  • Welcome from the Centre for Global eHealth Innovation
  • Projects Preview with local physicians and surgeons
  • Q&A
  • Facility Tour

Most importantly, meet the health professionals and technology innovators you have the chance to work with during the Hacking Heath Hackathon!

Space is limited so reserve your spot. If you cant join us at the Centre for eHealth Innovation, come to the pub for drinks afterward.

The After Party
Networking and discussions will continue with drinks at 8pm at the Duke of Somerset around the corner at 655 Bay Street. <somerset.thedukepubs.ca>
events.address: Toronto General Hospital  R. Fraser Elliott Building 4th Floor, 190 Elizabeth Street

events.name: AT&T Mobile App Hackathon - NXNE (Toronto)
events.about:
Have an app idea or need an app built for your business?

Mobile App Hackathon is an event produced by the AT&T Developer Program and Apigee that is designed for attendees (technical & non-technical) to build apps/mobile apps, get fed, compete for prizes across different categories and most importantly: meet new people and scout for teammates to work on new or current projects. Our hackathon will introduce you to the latest cutting edge tools to help deploy your own app with a website backend, fully hosted in the cloud.

As far as platforms are concerned, feel free to code in the language you feel most comfortable, whether its Objective C, Java, Javascript, HTML, C #, Dot Net, or XNA. Even if you are rusty with your programming, we will have live developer support from local senior developers as well as from AT&T, Sencha, and Apigee to help you code that much faster.


Event Schedule.  The following is a list of the weekends agenda:

  • 5PM - Friday Evening. AT&T Mobile App Hackathon. Kickoff event with drinks, networking, and developer dating which leads into idea pitches and team formation.
  • 10AM - Saturday Morning - AT&T Mobile App Hackathon. The fun continues with an all day hackathon. Work with the teams that you formed on Friday night to produce the app spec’d out the night before. Senseis will be available throughout the entire event to help you code up your solution. App submissions will be accepted throughout the day with a deadline of 7PM.
  • 7PM - Saturday Evening. Promptly at 7PM, teams will begin pitching their ventures. Pitches are limited to three (3) minutes per team.

Prizes. The following prizes are experiential and geared towards accelerating you towards a successful business as well as expanding your network and industry knowledge:

  • TBA

Judging Criteria. Apps will be judged based on the the criteria below and weighted accordingly.  

  • 33% Weight - Ability to clearly articulate what your app does
  • 33% Weight - Originality of idea
  • 33% Weight - Use of Node.JS, Sencha, cloud9ide.com, Heroku, and other technologies

 

 Sponsors

events.name: Ready.Set () {Code} Challenge - Toronto, ON
events.about:
Ready.Set () {Code} Challenge

 

Headphones on. Tilt the seat back. Just steady codin’ as the keys get tapped. Get ready, because Nokia Developer is about to turn your town into Dev City with its Ready.Set () {Code} Challenge.

 

We are hitting the road to 13-cities looking for developers who want to build an experience not just another app. To kick off the Ready.Set () {Code} Challenge, Nokia Developer will hold hackathons across the US and Canada beginning in May. You can sign up individually or form your own team to build the coolest, baddest apps for the Windows Phone platform and Nokia Lumia devices.

 

Prizes will be awarded on site at each event for the top 3 created apps, top student created app, and most Nokia-branded developer (use your imagination). App winners will be judged on creativity, usability, technical difficulty and app presentation.

 

1st place:                                                $500 gift card & Nokia Lumia 900

2nd place:                                               $250 gift card & Nokia Lumia 900

3rd place:                                               $100 gift card & Nokia Lumia 900

Student Winner:                                   $150 gift card & Nokia Lumia 900

Most Nokia-Branded Dev:                  $100 gift card & Nokia Lumia 900

 

At Nokia, we don’t have ordinary developers, so these won’t be ordinary hacks. We have some amazing experiences in store – like our Re-Charge Room - for developers to chill out between pounding out code. So come showoff your skills and earn rewards. Space will be limited so register early.

The Challenge is on. . . .Ready.Set () {Code}

 

Ready.Set () {Code} Challenge Schedule:

08:30 a.m.             Light breakfast and registration

09:00 a.m.             Welcome and competition overview

09:30 a.m.             Let the hacking begin!

12:30 p.m.             Lunch

07:00 p.m.             Show us your app/Dinner

08:00 p.m.             Winners announced

See rules here:

http://www.callingallinnovators.com/readysetchallenge/Toronto

events.name: RHoK Global June 2012: Toronto, Canada
events.about:
Toronto is Hacking for Social Good on June 1st-3rd, 2012. 

Join us for a weekend long code-a-thon and compete for the best prize for a completed hack! Technologists, Designers, Subject Matter Experts, Concerned Citizens, Data Enthusiats and Developers will join together for a weekend of problem solving, idea hacking and innovation. By putting creativity to these scenarios, code-sprints create technological solutions to problems ranging from bike accident mapping in Toronto to an application to build awareness around the access to clean water in some remote communities in Canada.

Were excited to announce that Toronto is partnering with commons11 to host a design jam on May 15th to hone down the challenges we will be working on during the Hackathon. For more information please seewww.rhokdesignjam.eventbrite.com.

All in the name of social change, Random Hacks of Kindness has evolved into a community of people around the world committed to making change through collaboration.

EVENT SCHEDULE:

More details to come soon!

Reception:

Friday June 1st: 6pm-9pm

Join us on Friday night where we will introduce Judges, special guests and celebrate the opening of the weekend!

Main Event:

Saturday June 2nd, 2011

  • Registration 9:00 - 10:00am
  • Introductions- 10:00-11:00am
  • Hacking: 11:00am- 5:00pm
  • First Day re-cap: 5:00pm
  • Hacking: 6:00pm-9:00pm

Sunday June 3rd, 2011

  • Hacking 10:00 am -3:00 pm
  • Pitch Competition and Judging 3:00pm-5:00pm

For sponsorship or to propose a challenge please contact Melanie Gorka at melanie.gorka@commons11.com. 

We are still looking for sponsors for food and prizes!!! Please forward this to your networks.

events.name: Random Hacks of Kindness Design Jam and Pitch Night
events.about: commons11 is hosting a design jam at Bento Miso for the upcoming Random Hacks of Kindness Hackathon (June 1-3rd, 2012). Weve invited subject matter experts to submit a social good challenge and are inviting software developers, human computer interaction/user experience specialists, designers and technologists will have the chance to come up ideas and prototypes that solve that challenge. Bring your creativity, ideas, and laptops and help solve pressing problems! Refreshments will be provided.

events.name: Android App Development, C3: Create, Cloud & Connect
events.about:
The Mobile Experience Innovation Centre (MEIC) and the Digital Arts and Technology Association (DATA) present the Mobile Developers & Designers of Toronto (MDOT) user group meeting for February 2012

Android App Development, C3: Create, Cloud & Connect

Wednesday, February 22, from 6: 30 p.m. to 9:00 p.m.

Schedule:

6:30 - 7: 00   Pizza & pop served

7:00 - 7:30   Programmers Progress (with apologies to John Bunyan)

Dr. David Forster - Deeper Reality

A year in the life of a seasoned programmer developing a mobile app for the
Android platform, highlighting the differences in designing and developing
for Android compared to other platforms, and discovering along the way the
myriad mechanisms needed to complete what initially appeared to be a simple
program.

Dr. David Forster, head of Deeper Reality, is a software developer and
teacher with many years of experience in a wide range of operating systems,
programming languages and application areas. Most recently, he has been
concentrating on mobile development for the Android platform,  with a
particular focus on Augmented Reality.

7:30 - 8:00   The Cloud and Your Android App

Atley Hunter – Altus Group

See how you can compete with the big boys on all the phone platforms simply
by tapping into the power of the Cloud. With Windows Azure as your backend
and toolkit for Android that makes app development simple, you’ll be
building mobile apps that can scale and reach the world in no time. By the
end of this session, you’ll know how to utilize the latest in Cloud
technologies for your Android app development needs

Atley Hunter has been a developer for more than 15 years and also a mobile
developer. With over 30 apps under his belt and numerous talks, blog posts
and HackFests, Atley is continually working to expand his development
knowledge and share it to anyone who wants to know. Atley is never far from
reach and always happy to help.

8:00 - 8:15   Break

8:15 - 8:45   Mobile Social Media on Android: Connecting Dots

Sebastian Villa - Villa Media

You just finished building your Android app, it is available in the Android
Market and your are hoping for at least a few thousand downloads; after all
it is such a cool app, right? This is only a small piece of the big picture.
Leverage the power of social networks and their robust programming platforms
through Android specific SDKs and APIs. Inspire conversations and develop
virtual communities all from within your app; let it connect the dots.

Sebastian Villa is a web, mobile and social media development expert and
researcher with a focus on multi-platform architecture. From the early days
of ActionScript to the latest advances in web and mobile programming
platforms, over the past 12 years Sebastian has worked with numerous brands
in different industries, helping them connect multiple back and front-end
technologies to power robust and engaging interactive experiences,
strategically architected and programmed to maximize utilization of social
media. 

8:45 - 9:00   Q&A

9:00   End

This event is a pilot initiative between MEIC and DATAs MDOT user group. Hosted by OCAD University.

events.name: Accelerator Workshop
events.about:
Accelerator Workshops are the key resource for entrepreneurs who would like to launch new Cloud Ventures, providing a key foundation for our virtual incubator services.

The principle activity is a business plan hackathon. Read more in this blog.

Topics for this workshop will include:

  • Government Cloud Computing - Market opportunities
  • Digital Identity and single sign-on
  • Cloud Privacy and Security best practices
  • Enterprise search

In particular we will have a key focus on Cloud BCP - Business Continuity Planning, and the opportunities this field presents for industry channel partners.

events.name: RHoK Global December 2011: Toronto, Canada
events.about: Our fourth global Random Hacks of Kindness event will bring big change. As announced at our last global event in June, RHoK has broadened its scope beyond its origins in Disaster Risk Management (DRM) to include all development sectors. The global water community came together for a Water Hackathon in 10 cities this October, and efforts to hack autism with touch technology are already underway. Were excited to announce that Toronto is partnering with Open Data Hackathon Day to hack on December 3 & 4th. The Hackathon is pleased to welcome the University of Toronto, Commons11, CSI and Nokia as sponsors and community partners.The Toronto and Montreal communities have answered to a call for developers, subject matter experts and volunteers to come together for a weekend of problem solving, idea hacking and innovation. All in the name of social change, Random Hacks of Kindness has evolved into a community of people around the world committed to making change through collaboration.Toronto will hack on problems from the Toronto Cycling Community, WaterVoices and more will be added in the lead up to the event.Date and Location:Friday, December 2, 2011 - Location and Time to be determined.Saturday December 3. 2011 10am-hacking endsSunday, December 4, 2011 10am-6:00pmCSI Annex First Floor720 Bathurst StreetToronto, ONOn Friday December 2, we will have guest speakers from the organizations that have submitted problem definitions and our guest judge panel, including Andrew Overholt and host a meet and greet night for developers.  For more information please contact Melanie Gorka atmelanie.gorka@gmail.com. We are still looking for sponsors, problem defintions and open data hack projects!!
